fields.headline: Guardian University Awards winners announced
fields.bodyText: The winners of the 2016 Guardian University Awards were announced at a ceremony this evening (16 March 2015) at the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA). The awards, running for its fourth year, recognise excellence in Britain’s best universities and set the benchmark for higher education excellence. This year’s ceremony was introduced by Judy Friedberg, and hosted by Paul Sinha. Judy Friedberg, universities editor, said: “We’ve had a record number of entries for this year’s awards and the standard of entries is awe-inspiring. University professionals around the UK have been collaborating and innovating to change lives on their own campuses, in their regions, and around the world. We’re delighted to be able to recognise their vision and their hard work.” This year saw a new award - Digital Innovation - which was awarded to the University of Kent university for ‘Looking out for Lottie’ – a simulation to tackle online grooming. Other notable winners include Goldsmiths University for its work on increasing student diversity and widening participation for ‘Open Book’ which works closely with a network of agencies to support people from a wide range of ‘non-traditional’ backgrounds including offending, addiction and mental health, and the University of Huddersfield for Buildings that Inspire with Heritage Quay. Winners receive a Guardian University Awards trophy and are profiled on the Higher Education and Guardian Students networks, as well a featuring in the Guardian University Award Ideas Bank and the University Guide. The full list of winners are as follows: Advancing Staff Equality - Swansea University Buildings that inspire - University of Huddersfield Business Partnership - Coventry University Digital Innovation - University of Kent Employability - Queen Mary University of London Entrepreneurship - University of Leeds International projects - University of Glasgow Marketing and communications campaign - Harper Adams University Research Impact - Newcastle University Sustainability project - Royal Agricultural University Social and community impact - Nottingham Trent University Student diversity and widening participation - Goldsmiths University Student experience - University of Essex Teaching excellence - Buckinghamshire New University Inspiring Leader - Ian Dunn, deputy vice-chancellor student experience, Coventry University More information about the awards can be found here. -Ends- For more information please contact: media.enquiries@theguardian.com or 020 335 33696 or visit theguardian.com for more information about the awards and a full list of judges. Notes to editors About University Awards For more information about the awards, judges and categories please visit the University Awards site. About Guardian News & Media Guardian News & Media (GNM) publishes theguardian.com, one of the largest English-speaking quality newspaper websites in the world. Since launching its US and Australia digital editions in 2011 and 2013 respectively, traffic from outside of the UK now represents over two-thirds of the Guardian’s total digital audience. In the UK, GNM publishes the Guardian newspaper six days a week, first published in 1821, and the world’s oldest Sunday newspaper, The Observer. The Guardian is most recently renowned for its Pulitzer Prize and Emmy-winning revelations based on the disclosures made by whistleblower Edward Snowden. In 2014, the Guardian was named newspaper and website of the year at the Society of Editors UK Press Awards and is the most trusted news source in the UK (Ofcom digital media report, 2014). The Guardian is also known for its globally acclaimed investigation into phone hacking, the launch of its groundbreaking digital-first strategy in 2011 and its trailblazing partnership with WikiLeaks in 2010.
